content.description: A nice crack boulder problem.  Jam that sucker all the way to the top.  Its fingers and intuitive.
content.location: Not visible from the trail.  Walk past the Green Block Arete to the obviously clean and tall face (opp side from the trail.)

content.description: The obvious line of holds a bit right of the crack.  Follow the generously featured, tall face to the top.  Be careful, this one is tall (but easy up high)
content.location: Not visible from the trail.  Walk past the Green Block Arete to the obviously clean and tall face (opp side from the trail.)

content.description: Not really a project, but I guess the name stuck.  This problem is the best way to brush the holds on the Green Block Test Piece.  Climb the arete, then traverse left to the finishing jug on the GBTP.  Either jump, or traverse back right and jump.
content.location: The right arete facing the Green Block Test Piece (along the main trail.)

content.description: Start on the far left side of the boulder and traverse the entire boulder, finishing up the arete.  This one is harder if you are short (the good holds and good feet are a stretch for me at 5'8")
content.location: Not visible from the trail.  Walk past the Green Block Arete to the obviously clean and tall face (opp side from the trail.)

content.description: Stand-start on obvious holds and figure out a tweaky sequence on bad holds to the jug.  This problem on a good day feels V4 at best and impossible on dank days.  I almost gave this one a V6 in the guide, but at the last minute, chickened out.  Originally rated V4 by Steve Cater who nabbed the FA.
content.location: The obvious line on the center of the face of the Green Block. (Visible from the trail.)

content.description: Sit-start and follow the well featured arete to the top.  A bit of a highball, with a bad tree landing.  None the less its quite safe.
content.location: From the trail, this is the left arete, which is about five feet left of the obvious Green Block Test Piece

content.description: Climb the gorgeously featured, tall face a few feet left of the right arete.
content.location: Not visible from the trail.  Walk past the Green Block Arete to the obviously clean and tall face (opp side from the trail.)
